Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Brooke Ullery is "Algebraic Geometry." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Utah, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Aaron Bertram.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Throughout the course of Brooke Ullery's NSF postdoctoral fellowship, she wrote three papers on measures of irrationality.

The first year of her fellowship was spent at the University of Utah, where she was able to work with Aaron Bertram, an expert in the field of algebraic geometry. During her time there, she coauthored a paper with F. Bastianelli, P. De Poi, L. Ein, and R. Lazarsfeld on measures of irrationality for hypersurfaces. This paper opened an area of research that has since interested many other mathematicians, and inspired several additional papers.

During the second and third year of her fellowship, Ullery was at Harvard University. Her next paper was coauthored with an undergraduate student, James Hotchkiss, who is now in graduate school at the University of Michigan studying algebraic geometry. This paper was on the gonality of complete intersection curves. Complete intersection curves are  examples in algebraic geometry, and the paper computed their gonality, one of the main invariants of a curve.

After that paper was completed, Ullery worked on a paper with David Stapleton, a postdoctoral researcher at the University of California - San Diego, in which they computed measures of irrationality for several more examples of algebraic varities. 

In addition, during the period of her fellowship, Ullery served on two panels at conferences for women in mathematics.
